meta.description: Complete archive taxonomy with structure and descriptions

Applications.description:
Large, mode-shifting creative or technical environments.
These are tool ecosystems, not source code or projects.
Examples include game engines, DAWs, notation tools, and IDEs.

tasks.3D:
Three-dimensional modeling and procedural world-building environments.
Tools for spatial thinking, geometry, and form.
tasks.Game_Engines:
Interactive simulation and game development environments.
Tools for building real-time systems and virtual worlds.
tasks.Audio:
Audio production and manipulation environments.
Recording, editing, mixing, and sound experimentation.
tasks.Music_Theory:
Music notation and theory-focused tools.
Used for analysis, composition, and score-based thinking.
tasks.Visual_Design:
Visual composition and design tools.
Raster and vector-based image creation and editing.
tasks.Video:
Video editing and post-production environments.
Used for assembling, grading, and rendering moving images.
tasks.Writing:
Writing and thinking environments.
Tools that shape how long-form text is produced and organized.
tasks.Electronics:
Embedded systems and hardware programming environments.
Tools tied to physical devices and microcontrollers.
tasks.IDEs:
Integrated development environments.
General-purpose coding workspaces, kept intentionally minimal.

apps.Blender: 3D creation suite for modeling, animation, rendering, and procedural workflows.
apps.Unreal: High-performance game engine for real-time simulation and interactive worlds.
apps.Godot: Lightweight, open-source game engine emphasizing simplicity and rapid iteration.
apps.Audacity: Audio editor for recording, trimming, and basic sound manipulation.
apps.Reaper: Highly configurable digital audio workstation focused on precision and scripting.
apps.MuseScore: Music notation software for score writing, analysis, and playback.
apps.GIMP: Raster-based image editor for photo manipulation and visual design.
apps.DaVinci_Resolve: Professional video editing and color grading environment.
apps.Obsidian: Markdown-based writing environment for linked notes and long-form thinking.
apps.LaTeX_Toolchain: Document preparation environment for structured, typeset writing.
apps.Arduino_IDE: Integrated environment for programming Arduino-compatible microcontrollers.
apps.PlatformIO: Embedded development ecosystem supporting multiple boards and frameworks.
apps.VSCode: Extensible code editor and development environment.
apps.Atom: Hackable text editor used as a lightweight IDE.

Audio.description:
Non-music audio artifacts and audio work-in-progress.
Recordings, experiments, stems, sound design, and cooked audio.

descriptions.Recordings:
Captured audio from the physical world.
Live recordings, voice takes, instrument captures, and raw source material.
descriptions.Experiments:
Exploratory and provisional audio work.
Half-formed ideas, sound tests, sketches, and throwaway explorations.
descriptions.Programmatic:
Audio generated or manipulated through code.
Algorithmic composition, DSP experiments, scripts, and computational sound.
descriptions.AI:
Audio created or transformed using machine learning systems.
Model outputs, training artifacts, prompts, and AI-assisted sound work.

Books.description:
Long-form written works intended to be read as books.
PDF, EPUB, MOBI, and similar formats. Mostly read-only.

descriptions.Books:
Long-form works intended for slow reading and sustained thought.
This collection is organized to support browsing, wandering, and curiosity,
not obligation or completion tracking.
descriptions.Mathematics:
Mathematical texts organized by domain and mode of thinking.
These shelves are meant to be browsed, revisited, and explored non-linearly.
descriptions.Science:
Scientific works exploring the natural world.
Organized by discipline and conceptual focus rather than textbook sequence.
descriptions.Philosophy:
Philosophical works organized by questions, traditions, and modes of inquiry.
This space supports reflection rather than systematic study.
descriptions.Literature:
Literary works organized by aesthetic tradition and narrative mode.
These shelves invite wandering based on tone, voice, and imaginative posture.
descriptions.History:
Historical works organized by era and thematic focus.
Intended for contextual understanding rather than chronological completeness.
descriptions.Computing:
Books about computation, software, and digital systems.
Focused on ideas, architecture, and practice rather than specific tools.
descriptions.Psychology:
Works exploring mind, behavior, and cognition.
Organized by perspective rather than clinical or academic taxonomy.
descriptions.Art:
Books about visual art, aesthetics, and built environments.
These shelves support visual thinking and historical context.
descriptions.Music:
Books about music as structure, history, and cultural practice.
Separate from listening collections; focused on understanding and reflection.
descriptions.Misc:
Books that do not yet have a clear home.
This is a temporary holding space, not a permanent category.

Code.description:
Source code and scripts.
Repositories, utilities, experiments, and executable logic.

descriptions.Libraries:
Reusable code organized by language.
Packages, modules, and standalone libraries intended for import.
descriptions.Tools:
Executable utilities and scripts.
Code that does something when run, not imported.
descriptions.Learning:
Educational code and exercises.
Code written to learn, not to ship.
descriptions.Experiments:
Exploratory and throwaway code.
Ideas tested quickly without polish or permanence.
descriptions.Reference:
Code kept for reference, not execution.
Patterns, templates, and configuration examples.

Compressed.description:
Archive containers such as zip, tar, and 7z files.
This is a staging area, not a permanent home.

descriptions.Downloads:
Compressed files from the web.
Downloaded archives awaiting extraction and classification.
descriptions.Backups:
Compressed backup archives.
Snapshots and exports from other systems or services.
descriptions.Exports:
Compressed exports from applications.
Project bundles, database dumps, and tool-specific archives.
descriptions.Unknown:
Compressed files of unclear origin.
Awaiting inspection before classification or deletion.

Data.description:
Structured data artifacts.
CSV, JSON, Parquet, logs, generated datasets, and analysis outputs.

descriptions.Tabular:
Row-and-column data formats.
Data that fits naturally into spreadsheets and dataframes.
descriptions.Structured:
Hierarchical and nested data formats.
Configuration files, API responses, and structured documents.
descriptions.Databases:
Database files and exports.
Portable database containers and migration artifacts.
descriptions.Logs:
Log files and event records.
Time-series data from applications and systems.
descriptions.Generated:
Programmatically created data.
Outputs from models, simulations, and automated collection.
descriptions.Geospatial:
Geographic and spatial data.
Maps, coordinates, and location-based datasets.

Docs.description:
Documents that are not books.
Manuals, contracts, receipts, reference PDFs, and administrative files.

descriptions.Reference:
Technical reference materials.
Documentation meant to be consulted, not read cover-to-cover.
descriptions.Administrative:
Business and administrative paperwork.
Financial, legal, and transactional documents.
descriptions.Personal:
Personal identity and life documents.
Records that define identity, history, and credentials.
descriptions.Correspondence:
Written communication archives.
Letters, emails, and messages worth preserving.
descriptions.Presentations:
Visual presentation materials.
Slides, posters, and materials designed for display.

Images.description:
Still images.
Photography, scans, artwork, screenshots, and visual assets.

descriptions.Photography:
Photographs taken with cameras.
Organized by context and subject matter.
descriptions.Scans:
Digitized physical materials.
Documents, artwork, and film converted to digital format.
descriptions.Screenshots:
Screen captures from devices.
Visual records of digital interfaces and content.
descriptions.Artwork:
Created visual art.
Original artwork, both digital and digitized traditional.
descriptions.Assets:
Reusable visual components.
Icons, textures, and design elements.

Intake.description:
Temporary landing zone for unclassified material.
Nothing here is considered organized or permanent.

descriptions.Downloads:
Files downloaded from the web.
Browser downloads awaiting classification.
descriptions.Desktop:
Files saved to desktop.
Quick saves and temporary desktop clutter.
descriptions.Mobile:
Files transferred from mobile devices.
Photos, screenshots, and downloads from phones and tablets.
descriptions.Email:
Attachments saved from email.
Files extracted from email awaiting proper placement.
descriptions.Transfers:
Files received from other people or systems.
Shared files, AirDrop, and external transfers.
descriptions.Unsorted:
Files of unknown origin.
Catch-all for anything that doesn't fit elsewhere in Intake.

Journal.description:
Chronological personal writing.
Reflections, logs, and time-ordered narrative entries.

descriptions.Daily:
Daily journal entries.
Day-to-day reflections and observations.
descriptions.Weekly:
Weekly reviews and reflections.
Summaries and patterns across the week.
descriptions.Monthly:
Monthly reviews and retrospectives.
Longer-arc reflections and goal tracking.
descriptions.Annual:
Annual reviews and year-end reflections.
Big-picture thinking and year-over-year patterns.
descriptions.Dreams:
Dream journal entries.
Records of dreams and nocturnal experiences.
descriptions.Gratitude:
Gratitude entries.
Intentional acknowledgment of positive experiences.
descriptions.Freewrite:
Unstructured freewriting.
Stream-of-consciousness writing without format.

Movies.description:
Cinematic works.
Feature films, documentaries, and shorts treated as cinema.

descriptions.Drama:
Character-driven narratives exploring human experience.
Stories that emphasize emotional depth over spectacle.
descriptions.Comedy:
Films designed to provoke laughter.
Humor as primary mode of engagement.
descriptions.Thriller:
Suspense-driven narratives.
Tension and uncertainty as core experience.
descriptions.Science_Fiction:
Speculative futures and technological premises.
Ideas and consequences over action.
descriptions.Fantasy:
Magical worlds and mythic structures.
Stories that transcend mundane reality.
descriptions.Horror:
Films designed to frighten and unsettle.
Fear as aesthetic experience.
descriptions.Action:
Spectacle-driven physical conflict.
Movement, combat, and kinetic energy.
descriptions.Documentary:
Non-fiction filmmaking.
Reality captured and shaped by a point of view.
descriptions.Animation:
Animated films across traditions.
Movement created frame by frame.
descriptions.Art_House:
Experimental and auteur-driven cinema.
Films that prioritize vision over convention.
descriptions.World_Cinema:
Films organized by region of origin.
Browsing by cultural tradition.
descriptions.Classic:
Historical periods of cinema.
Films from defined eras of filmmaking.

Music.description:
Music intended for listening and browsing.
Organized for discovery, adjacency, and strolling.

descriptions.Classical:
Western art music tradition.
Organized by period, form, and instrumentation.
descriptions.Jazz:
American improvisational tradition.
Organized by era, style, and approach.
descriptions.Blues:
African American roots music.
Foundation of rock, jazz, and soul.
descriptions.Country:
American roots music from the rural South and West.
Storytelling, tradition, and evolution.
descriptions.Rock:
Guitar-driven popular music.
Organized by subgenre, era, and attitude.
descriptions.Metal:
Heavy, distorted, intense.
Organized by subgenre and extremity.
descriptions.Punk:
Fast, loud, anti-establishment.
DIY ethos and subcultural identity.
descriptions.Electronic:
Synthesized and computer-generated music.
Organized by tempo, texture, and scene.
descriptions.Hip_Hop:
Beat-driven vocal music.
Organized by era, region, and style.
descriptions.Pop:
Popular music crafted for broad appeal.
Melody, hooks, and production polish.
descriptions.Reggae:
Jamaican music tradition.
Offbeat rhythms, bass-heavy, culturally rich.
descriptions.Soul_RnB:
African American vocal traditions.
Emotion, groove, and expression.
descriptions.Folk:
Acoustic, traditional-rooted music.
Stories, simplicity, and heritage.
descriptions.World:
Music from global traditions.
Organized by region and style.
descriptions.Experimental:
Boundary-pushing sound art.
Music that challenges definition.
descriptions.New_Age:
Relaxation and spiritual music.
Ambient, healing, and contemplative.
descriptions.Soundtrack:
Music composed for visual media.
Organized by medium and purpose.

Notes.description:
Short-form thinking artifacts.
Scratch notes, research fragments, ideas, and provisional text.

descriptions.Research:
Notes from research and investigation.
Raw material gathered during inquiry.
descriptions.Ideas:
Seeds and sparks of possibility.
Thoughts worth capturing before they fade.
descriptions.Learning:
Notes from learning activities.
What was absorbed, summarized, or captured.
descriptions.Work:
Work-related notes.
Professional context and decisions.
descriptions.Personal:
Personal notes and reflections.
Private thinking not for external use.
descriptions.Reference:
Quick reference materials.
Information kept for easy lookup.

Projects.description:
Active and evolving workspaces.
Messy by design. Completed outputs should be promoted elsewhere.

descriptions.Software:
Software development projects.
Code-heavy work with build artifacts and dependencies.
descriptions.Writing:
Writing projects.
Long-form writing with drafts, research, and revisions.
descriptions.Creative:
Creative projects.
Art, music, video, and other creative work.
descriptions.Research:
Research projects.
Investigations, experiments, and exploratory work.
descriptions.Learning:
Learning projects.
Structured learning efforts and skill development.
descriptions.Personal:
Personal projects.
Life projects, organization, and self-improvement.

Systems.description:
System-level artifacts.
Backups, disk images, installers, and configuration snapshots.

descriptions.Backups:
Backup archives and snapshots.
Point-in-time copies of systems and data.
descriptions.Disk_Images:
Disk and partition images.
Bootable and restorable disk captures.
descriptions.Installers:
Installation media and packages.
Software needed for system setup.
descriptions.Configuration:
System and application configuration.
Settings, dotfiles, and setup scripts.
descriptions.Logs:
Archived system logs.
Historical logs preserved for reference.

Video.description:
Non-cinematic moving images.
Home videos, lectures, screen recordings, and clips.

descriptions.Personal:
Personal video recordings.
Life moments captured on video.
descriptions.Educational:
Learning and educational videos.
Videos watched or saved for learning.
descriptions.Screen_Recordings:
Captured screen activity.
Recordings of computer or device screens.
descriptions.Creative:
Creative video work.
Video projects and raw materials.
descriptions.Clips:
Short video clips.
Saved clips from various sources.
descriptions.Streams:
Streamed content.
Live stream recordings and archives.
